column4: Hi.  I have ubuntu 9.10 64 bit, gnome.   Some webpages take ages to download.   Pages seem to stop downloading in some cases for a good while before continuing.  Pressing reload often helps.  Applies to Chrome and Epiphany and did with Firefox before I threw it out.  I'm on wireless.  Direct connection is better but not good at all.  Can someone point me in the right direction here?
try going to the terminal and type ping google.com and see how your connection is
Seems ok.  No packet loss, below 70ms.
70's is starting to get a little high
try wired to see if it goes down
My beloved son left my cable at friends house.  Can't check it right now.  But I'm a bit far from Google.  Domestic ping around 16ms.
is it just specific webpages that are slow to load or even one's with a good ping?

Krazderek: Some pages are good.  Pages with alot of images are often bad.  Sometimes (too often) pages seem to choke on css.  Pages are displayed without formatting sometimes and pages with heavy css seem to be troublesome even if there are not many images.  I've tried to disable and remove flash completely with no effect
have isolated the problem to the one machine on your local network to rule out your internet connection / router ?

This machine is the only linux machine on the net.  I've experimented with all other machines shut down.  I have tried most suggestions to network tuning I've found (mru etc) in vain.  What troubles me is that it happens on all browser I've tried.  What's common to them?  Since reloading pages often helps I thought maybe it could be some cache problem.  Or - some problems loading from mediaservers?

i doubt you'd have caching problems across multiple browsers... i've had problems with firefox not working with very specific pages unless i press reload multipl times but it was always limited to that browser
Sipior: dns is under 16ms away.  I think it is cached in the router but not sure
Sipior: This seems good advice.  I'll check on this - but I gotta run now.  I'll get back to you later if that's ok
